note.title: Integrating Products of Powers of Sin and Cos

pageProps.body:
Integrating Products of Powers of Sin and Cos

Now that we know Integrating Powers of sin x and cos x, we can apply the half-angle formulas to integrate products of powers of sin and cos.

Example

Evaluate the following integrals:

  1. ∫sin⁡4xcos⁡2x dx\int{\sin^4{x}\cos^2{x}}\,dx∫sin4xcos2xdx
  2. ∫sin⁡3xcos⁡−2x dx\int{\sin^3{x}\cos^{-2}{x}}\,dx∫sin3xcos−2xdx

Solution

  1. When both powers are even positive integers, the half-angle formulas can be used:

    ∫sin⁡4xcos⁡2x dx=∫(1−cos⁡2x2)2(1+cos⁡2x2)2 dx\int{\sin^4{x}\cos^2{x}}\,dx=\int{(\frac{1-\cos{2x}}{2})^2(\frac{1+\cos{2x}}{2})^2}\,dx∫sin4xcos2xdx=∫(21−cos2x​)2(21+cos2x​)2dx

    When expanded...

    =18∫(1−cos⁡2x−cos⁡22x+cos⁡32x) dx=\frac18\int{(1-\cos{2x}-\cos^2{2x}+\cos^3{2x})}\,dx=81​∫(1−cos2x−cos22x+cos32x)dx

    The third term in the integrand is rewritten with a half angle formula. For the last term, a factor of cos⁡2x\cos{2x}cos2x is written in terms of sin⁡2x\sin{2x}sin2x to prepare for a uuu-substitution:

    ∫sin⁡4xcos⁡2x dx=18∫(1−cos2x−(1+cos⁡4x2) dx+18∫(1−sin⁡22x)cos⁡2x dx\int{\sin^4{x}\cos^2{x}}\,dx=\frac18\int{(1-cos{2x}-(\frac{1+\cos{4x}}{2})\,dx}+\frac18\int{(1-\sin^2{2x})\cos{2x}}\,dx∫sin4xcos2xdx=81​∫(1−cos2x−(21+cos4x​)dx+81​∫(1−sin22x)cos2xdx

    Finally, the integrals are evaluated, using the substitution u=sin⁡2xu=\sin{2x}u=sin2x for the second integral. After simplification, we find that

    ∫sin⁡4xcos⁡2x dx=116x−164sin⁡4−148sin⁡32x+C.\int{\sin^4{x}\cos^2{x}}\,dx=\frac{1}{16}x-\frac{1}{64}\sin{4}-\frac{1}{48}\sin^3{2x}+C\text.∫sin4xcos2xdx=161​x−641​sin4−481​sin32x+C.

  2. When at least one power is odd, the following approach works:

    ∫sin⁡3xcos⁡−2x dx=∫sin2xcos⁡−2xsin⁡x dx\int{\sin^3{x}\cos^{-2}{x}}\,dx=\int{sin^2{x}\cos^{-2}{x}\sin{x}}\,dx∫sin3xcos−2xdx=∫sin2xcos−2xsinxdx
    =∫(1−cos⁡2x)cos⁡−2xsin⁡x dx=\int{(1-\cos^2{x})\cos^{-2}{x}\sin{x}}\,dx=∫(1−cos2x)cos−2xsinxdx
    =−∫(1−u2)u−2 du=-\int{(1-u^2)u^{-2}}\,du=−∫(1−u2)u−2du
    =∫(1−u−2) du=u+1u+C=\int{(1-u^{-2})}\,du=u+\frac1u+C=∫(1−u−2)du=u+u1​+C
    =cos⁡x+sec⁡x+C.=\cos{x}+\sec{x}+C\text.=cosx+secx+C.
